thread.title: The week in numbers to July 3
thread.title_full: The week in numbers to July 3

author: news.com.au
title: The week in numbers to July 3
text:
THE big and small numbers that grabbed attention - or should have - in the business world over the past week.
MONDAY: $35 billion - The share market plunged by around 2.2 per cent, wiping more than $35 billion from its value, after the collapse of Greece debt relief talks.
Tuesday: 1.28 pct - The final day of the financial year, and the share market booked a rise of just 1.28 per cent for the 12 months. Hardly shooting the lights out. Wednesday: 215,000 - That's the number of new dwellings Commonwealth Bank senior economist Michael Workman is predicting will be built over the next year. Is a building-led economic recovery finally arriving? Thursday: $US2.3 trillion - California has slipped down to eighth on list of the world's largest economies. Brazil's gross domestic product has risen to a value of more than $US2.3 trillion ($A3.01 trillion), moving it back above the US west coast state on the World Bank's list. Friday: 21 pct - Iron ore exports from Port Hedland, the world's largest iron ore port, increased 21 per cent in the past year, to 439.6 million tonnes. That's despite prices almost halving in that period to around $US50 a tonne.
